``` {r read-data, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
#The abundance matrix generated via salmon and tximport to be used for the DE analysis
txi.nigra <- readRDS("data/txi.salmon_SN.RDS")

#The samples file generated for tximport
samples <- read.table("data/SN_samples.txt", header = TRUE)

samples$group <- factor(paste0(samples$sex, samples$organ))

#Changing "Gonad" to be more descriptive --> testes or ovaries
samples$organ <- ifelse(samples$sex == "F" & samples$organ == "Gonad",
                        paste0("Ovaries"),

samples$organ <- as.factor(samples$organ)

#Format colData to be used in the tau function
colData <- as.data.frame(samples)
rownames(colData) <- samples$ID
```

# Differential Expression Analysis
The main goal of this analysis is to relate measure of pleiotropic constraints (tissue specificity) to sex bias. In order to do that I need to combine my sex-bias data that I generated in a separate .Rmd with the tau values I will be generating in this document.

Here I am reading in the sex-bias datasets that correspond to each of the organ's single-factor analysis. These datasets include all of the genes where the p-value was not equal to "NA".

```{r read-in-sb-datasets}
liver_res <- read.csv("data/liver_res.csv", 
                      row.names = 1, 
                      header = TRUE)
gill_res <- read.csv("data/gill_res.csv", 
                      row.names = 1, 
                      header = TRUE)
gonad_res <- read.csv("data/gonad_res.csv", 
                      row.names = 1, 
                      header = TRUE)
```

# Calculating Tissue Specificity
To estimate tissue specificity, the TPM estimates are needed which is the number of transcripts from a particular gene normalized first by gene length, and then by sequencing depth (in millions) in the sample. The output quant.sf files from salmon have the following format:

```
Name | Length | EffectiveLength | TPM | NumReads

```

## Pulling out TPM values 
From the Salmon outputs I pulled out the TPM values from each sample.

```{r getTPMs}

#Get the list of file names/paths for all of the quant.sf files
files <- list.files(pattern = ".sf", path = "data/nigra_expression_files",
                    full.names = TRUE)

#For each quant.sf file pull out the TPM column
tpms <- do.call(cbind, lapply(files, function(file){

  dat <- read.delim(file, row.names = "Name")
  tpm <- dat["TPM"]
  colnames(tpm) <- gsub("data/nigra_expression_files/(.*)_quant.sf","\\1",file)
  
  return(tpm)
}))

#Remove the sample that was removed in the differential expression analysis 
tpms <- tpms[, !(colnames(tpms) %in% c("S34"))]
```

## Filtering the TPM dataset
I want to filter the TPM dataset to remove a few things. These include similar things that I filtered out in the DESeq2 datasets prior to performing the differential expression analysis. This includes:
  
  1. Keeping only rows that weren't filtered out in the DEseq2 dataset due to low counts (rowSum $\le$ 10).
  2. Removing the rows that corresponded to genes that were "outliers" in the DEseq2 analysis.
  3. Removing the samples related to individual SNT8F2 (sample S34).

This will be imperfect filtering in this case because I did individual single-factor analysis within each organ type. To try and make life easier, I am going to run the multi-factor analysis on the DESeq2 dataset and then apply the filtering from that onto the TPM dataset. 

It should also be noted that the DESeq2 filtering was done based off of the count data and not the TPMs, but as TPMs are just normalized counts they should be correlated and something that was had low gene counts should also have a low TPM and anything that was considered an outlier in the counts could also be an outlier in terms of TPM, but it may not be perfect.

```{r filterTPMs}
#Running the MF diff. expr. analysis
#Create the DESeq dataset
dds_SN <- DESeqDataSetFromTximport(txi.nigra,
                                   colData = samples,
                                   design = ~ group)

##Remove S34 from the dataset
dds_SN <- dds_SN[, !(dds_SN$ID %in% c("S34"))]

##Filter the dataset, only keeping rows that have at least 10 reads total
keep <- rowSums(counts(dds_SN)) >= 10 
dds_SN <- dds_SN[keep, ]

#Generate the expression values
dds_SN_exp <- DESeq(dds_SN)

#Filtering the tpm dataset
#Only keeping the rows that weren't filtered out due to low counts
tpms <- tpms[rownames(tpms) %in% rownames(dds_SN), ]

#Pulling out the geneIDs for genes that were categorized as "outliers" by DESeq2
#Calculating the Cooks threshold that would have been used
np <- length(resultsNames(dds_SN_exp))
nsamp <- ncol(dds_SN_exp)
cooks_thresh <- qf(0.99, df1 = np, df2 = nsamp-np)

out_ids <- names(mcols(dds_SN_exp)$maxCooks[mcols(dds_SN_exp)$maxCooks > cooks_thresh])

#Removing the rows in the tpm dataset that were deemed "outliers" by DESeq2
tpms <- tpms[!(rownames(tpms) %in% out_ids), ]

```

## Generating $\tau$
These filtered TPM estimates can then be used to estimate $\tau$, a tissue specificity estimator that can range from 0 to 1. $\tau$ is calculated for each tissue, $i$, as follows:

$$
\tau=\frac{\sum_i{[1-ln(TPM_i)/ln(TPM_{max})]}}{N-1}
$$

where $TPM_{max}$ is the maximum **average** TPM for a given tissue type, and $TPM_i$ is the **average** TPM for tissue $i$. If $\tau = 0$, that gene is evenly expressed across tissues; if $\tau=1$, the gene is expressed in an entirely tissue-specific fashion. Because TPM values approach 0 are impacted by sampling stochasticity, any genes that had an expression approaching 0 were set to $TPM=2$. 

```{r est_tauFXN}
#Function for estimating tau given the TPM matrix and metadata file
est_tau<-function(geneDat,colDat){
  
  #For each row in the TPM matrix cbind it with the metadata file,
  #this attaches organ type information to the TPM values
  tissue_dat<-data.frame(cbind(colDat,
                               geneDat))
  
  #For the TPM values approaching 0, set them to 2
  tissue_dat$geneDat[tissue_dat$geneDat < 2] <- 2
  
  
  #Get the average TPM for each tissue type (TPMi)
  tissue_avgs<-tapply(tissue_dat$geneDat,tissue_dat$organ,mean)
  
  #Get the maximum value from the average TPMS (TPMmax)
  tpmMax <- max(tissue_avgs, na.rm=TRUE)
    
  #IF running tau on JUST males of JUST females, this accounts for the
  #fact that ovary or testis will return an NA in the averaging
  if(length(unique(tissue_dat$organ)) == 3){
    tau <- sum(1-(log(tissue_avgs[unique(tissue_dat$organ)])/log(tpmMax)))/
      (length(unique(tissue_dat$organ))-1)
    
    return(tau)
  }
  
  #IF using the WHOLE dataset, calculate tau
  tau<-sum(1-(log(tissue_avgs)/log(tpmMax)))/(length(unique(tissue_dat$organ))-1)
  
  return(tau)
}

```


I then applied that function across each row in the TPMs matrix with my metadata stored in the object `colData`. The metadata file includes the sample ID, Sex, and Organ type for every column present in the TPM matrix.

I ran the $\tau$ function with the whole dataset, and then for just males and just females.

```{r calcTau}
colData <- colData[!(colData$ID %in% c("S34")),]

tau <- apply(tpms, 1, est_tau, colDat=colData)


tau_fem<-apply(tpms[,which(colData$sex=="F")], 1, est_tau,
               colData[which(colData$sex=="F"),])

tau_mal<-apply(tpms[,which(colData$sex=="M")], 1, est_tau,
               colData[which(colData$sex=="M"),])

```

```{r tauHist,fig.cap="Distribution of tissue specificity estimates for only the male samples (left) versus only the female samples (middle) versus the male samples and the female samples (right).", echo=FALSE}
par(mfrow=c(1,3))
hist(tau_mal,
     col="grey",
     xlab=expression(tau),
     ylab="Number of genes",
     main="Male-only")

hist(tau_fem,
     col="grey",
     xlab=expression(tau),
     ylab="Number of genes",
     main="Female-only")

hist(tau,
     col="grey",
     xlab=expression(tau),
     ylab="Number of genes",
     main="All samples")
```

We can see that the distribution of $\tau$ varies quite a bit between males, females, and all of the samples in the calculation (Fig. \@ref(fig:tauHist)). Because of this, I will likely have to run $\tau$ separately with male and female samples moving forward.

# Sex Bias and Tissue Specificity
Now that I have calculated $\tau$ I want to relate it back to information about sex bias to see what, if any, relationship exists. I am going to do this separately for the different organs to see if the relationship changes based on organ type.

## $\tau$ and logFC in sex-biased genes for each organ
A gene was determined to be sex-biased if it had a log-fold change $\ge |2|$ AND an adjusted p-value of $< 0.05$. Earlier I read in four datasets that contain information for all of the significantly expressed genes in each organ (i.e. the genes that were not given a p-value of NA from DESeq). 

From these datasets I can pull out the female- and male-biased genes to plot logFC against $\tau$ within the genes that are sex-biased.

```{r tau-v-bias, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Sex bias (in terms of the square root of the absolute value of the log2FoldChange) versus tissue specificity (tau) for all genes that are sex biased in the gonads, liver, skin, and brain."}

#Pull out the sex-biased genes (based on FC of >= |2| and padj of < 0.05) for each organ
liver_biased <- liver_res[which(abs(liver_res$log2FoldChange) >= 2 & liver_res$padj <= 0.05),]
gonad_biased <- gonad_res[which(abs(gonad_res$log2FoldChange) >= 2 & gonad_res$padj <= 0.05),]
gill_biased <- gill_res[which(abs(gill_res$log2FoldChange) >= 2 & gill_res$padj <= 0.05),]

#Merge the sex bias information with the tau values based on row names for each organ
liver_bias_tau <- merge(as.data.frame(liver_biased), as.data.frame(tau), by = "row.names")
gonad_bias_tau <- merge(as.data.frame(gonad_biased), as.data.frame(tau), by = "row.names")
gill_bias_tau <- merge(as.data.frame(gill_biased), as.data.frame(tau), by = "row.names")

#Plot the relationship between FC (bias) and tau for each organ
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 8.1), xpd=FALSE)
plot(sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau$log2FoldChange)),
     gonad_bias_tau$tau,
     pch=19,
     col = "#EEB42275",
     xlab="Sex bias (|log2 fold change|)",
     ylab=expression(tau["TPM"]))
points(sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau$log2FoldChange)),
     liver_bias_tau$tau,
     pch=19,
     col="#EE826275")
points(sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau$log2FoldChange)),
     gill_bias_tau$tau,
     pch=19,
     col = "#20B2AA75")


#Add the best fit lines
abline(lm(gonad_bias_tau$tau ~ sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau$log2FoldChange))), col="#EEB422", lwd = 3)
abline(lm(liver_bias_tau$tau ~ sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau$log2FoldChange))), col = "#EE8262", lwd = 3, lty = 2)
abline(lm(gill_bias_tau$tau ~ sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau$log2FoldChange))), col = "#20B2AA", lwd = 3, lty = 3)

#Add a legend
outer_legend("right",
             c("Gonad", "Liver", "Gill"),
             col = c("#EEB422", "#EE8262", "#20B2AA"),
             pch = 19,
             lwd = 3,
             bty = 'n',
             cex = 1.5,
             lty = 1:3,
             ncol = 1)


```

The absolute value of the log2 fold change was square root transformed. There appears to be a positive relationship between $\tau$ and sex bias for the gonads, liver, and gills (Fig. \@ref(fig:tau-v-bias)). We can look further into these relationships with a Spearman's rank correlation test. This was done between $\tau$ and the $|log2FoldChange|$ for each organ separately.

```{r tau-v-bias-cor, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
cor.test(gonad_bias_tau$tau, sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")
cor.test(liver_bias_tau$tau, sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")
cor.test(gill_bias_tau$tau, sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")

```

All three organs show significant positive correlations:

## $\tau$ and logFC for all the signficantly expressed genes in each organ
Only looking at the logFC for the sex-biased genes may be affecting the relationship that I am seeing between sex bias and $\tau$, especially in the organs where the samples size is very small if I am only including sex-biased genes (like the liver and gills). 

I used the same steps as above to see how the relationship changes when I add in ALL of the genes that are significantly expressed for each organ. In this datasets I have removed all rows where the adjusted p-value is NA (outliers and low-counts).

The absolute value of the log2 fold change was square root transformed. We can see similar patterns as when we only plotted the sex biased genes (Fig. \@ref(fig:tau-v-bias)) with the strongest relationship showing up in the gonads. When we add in all of the points, however, it seems that the best fit line for the liver and gills now points downward (Fig. \@ref(fig:tau-v-FC)). Let's see how the Spearman's rank correlation test have changed. This was done between $\tau$ and the $|log2FoldChange|$ for each organ separately.

## Categories of sex bias vs $\tau$

To further investigate the relationship between $\tau$ and sex biased and possibly get a cleaner idea of what may be going on I categorised the sex biased genes based on a series of logFC thresholds. After that I can plot $\tau$ against the bias level.

### Within the sex-biased genes

```{r bias-bin-cats, echo=FALSE}
#Create a long format dataset that has the tissue information, logFC, tau, and geneID 
logFC_long <- data.frame(
  tissue=c(rep("Gill", nrow(gill_bias_tau)),
           rep("Gonad", nrow(gonad_bias_tau)),
           rep("Liver", nrow(liver_bias_tau))),
  logFC=c(gill_bias_tau$log2FoldChange,
          gonad_bias_tau$log2FoldChange,
          liver_bias_tau$log2FoldChange),
  geneID=c(gill_bias_tau$Row.names,
           gonad_bias_tau$Row.names,
           liver_bias_tau$Row.names),
  tau=c(gill_bias_tau$tau,
        gonad_bias_tau$tau,
        liver_bias_tau$tau)
  )

#Add a column to denote female-biased or male biased
logFC_long$bias <- ifelse(logFC_long$logFC < 0, paste0("FB"), paste0("MB"))

#Categorize the degree of sex bias in each row
#Make a vector that contains all of the groupings
biased_bins <- c("low", "med", "high", "extreme", "sex-specific")

#Create a new column in the dataset and use ifelse statements to set the category limits
#abs(logFC) was used to account for the fem-biased genes possessing negative values
logFC_long$bias_cat <- ifelse(abs(logFC_long$logFC) >= 2 & abs(logFC_long$logFC) < 3, biased_bins[1],
                                   ifelse(abs(logFC_long$logFC) >= 3 & abs(logFC_long$logFC) < 5, biased_bins[2],
                                          ifelse(abs(logFC_long$logFC) >= 5 & abs(logFC_long$logFC) < 10,
                                                 biased_bins[3], 
                                                 biased_bins[4])
                                          )
                                   )

#Making sure the ordering stays correct
logFC_long$bias_cat <- factor(logFC_long$bias_cat,
    levels = biased_bins, ordered = TRUE)

#write.csv(logFC_long, "data/logFC_long_taubiasSB.csv", row.names = FALSE)

```

```{r tau-v-biascat-plot, echo=FALSE, fig.width=15, fig.height=8, fig.cap="Tissue specificity (tau) across the different bias levels. Colour denotes female-biased versus male biased and jitters were added to show all of the raw tau values."}
my_colors <- c("FB" = "#7fc97f", "MB" = "#beaed4")

plotdat<-ggplot(logFC_long,
       aes(x = bias_cat, y = tau, fill = bias)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = my_colors) +
  facet_grid(. ~ tissue) +
  theme(axis.line = element_blank(),
    plot.background = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_blank()) +
  labs(x="Bias Category", y=expression(tau["TPM"])) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Bias Level", order = 3))

plotdat + 
geom_point(data = logFC_long[logFC_long$bias == "MB",], 
           aes(x=as.numeric(bias_cat)+0.185, y=tau),
          size=0.4, 
          position = position_jitter(width = 0.15),
          bg=my_colors["MB"],
          col="black",pch=21
          )+ 
geom_point(data = logFC_long[logFC_long$bias == "FB",], 
           aes(x=as.numeric(bias_cat)-0.185, y=tau),
          size=0.4, 
          position = position_jitter(width = 0.15),
          bg=my_colors["FB"],
          col="black",pch=21
          )

```

```{r readin-sex-specific-genes}
#Specify the directory where Sex-specific gene files are located
ss_genes_path <- "data"

                                          pattern = "specific")

SN_sex_specific_genes <- list()

#Create a loop to read in all of the sex-specific genes
for(file_name in SN_sex_specific_genes_files){
  
  # Read the file and store it in a new object
  file_data <- read.table(file.path(ss_genes_path, file_name))
  
  #Add column names to the dataset
  colnames(file_data) <- c("trin_geneid")
  
  # Create a new object with a name based on the file name
  ss_name <- sub("_TRgenes.txt$", "", file_name) #Removes the file extension
  SN_sex_specific_genes[[ss_name]] <- file_data
}

# Sex Bias and Tissue Specificity
Now that I have calculated fem $\tau$ I want to relate it back to information about sex bias to see what, if any, relationship exists. I am going to do this separately for the different organs to see if the relationship changes based on organ type. I'll only be looking at female-biased genes.

## $\tau$ and logFC in female-biased genes for each organ
A gene was determined to be sex-biased if it had a log-fold change $\le -2$ AND an adjusted p-value of $< 0.05$. Earlier I read in four datasets that contain information for all of the significantly expressed genes in each organ (i.e., the genes that were not given a p-value of NA from DESeq). 

From these datasets I can pull out the female-biased genes to plot logFC against $\tau$ within the genes that are sex-biased.

```{r tau-v-bias-fem, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Sex bias (in terms of the square root of the absolute value of the log2FoldChange) versus tissue specificity (tau) for all genes that are sex biased in the gonads, liver, and skin."}

#Pull out the sex-biased genes (based on FC of <= -2 and padj of < 0.05) for each organ
liver_biased_fem <- liver_res[which(liver_res$log2FoldChange <= -2 & liver_res$padj <= 0.05),]
gonad_biased_fem <- gonad_res[which(gonad_res$log2FoldChange <= -2 & gonad_res$padj <= 0.05),]
gill_biased_fem <- gill_res[which(gill_res$log2FoldChange <= -2 & gill_res$padj <= 0.05),]


#Merge the sex bias information with the tau values based on row names for each organ
liver_bias_tau_fem <- merge(as.data.frame(liver_biased_fem), as.data.frame(tau_fem), by = "row.names")
gonad_bias_tau_fem <- merge(as.data.frame(gonad_biased_fem), as.data.frame(tau_fem), by = "row.names")
gill_bias_tau_fem <- merge(as.data.frame(gill_biased_fem), as.data.frame(tau_fem), by = "row.names")

#Plot the relationship between FC (bias) and tau for each organ
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 8.1), xpd=FALSE)
plot(sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange)),
     gonad_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem,
     pch=19,
     col = "#EEB42275",
     xlab="Sex bias (|log2 fold change|)",
     ylab=expression(tau["TPM"]))
points(sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange)),
     liver_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem,
     pch=19,
     col="#EE826275")
points(sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange)),
     gill_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem,
     pch=19,
     col = "#20B2AA75")


#Add the best fit lines
abline(lm(gonad_bias_tau_fem$tau ~ sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange))), col="#EEB422", lwd = 3)
abline(lm(liver_bias_tau_fem$tau ~ sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange))), col = "#EE8262", lwd = 3, lty = 2)
abline(lm(gill_bias_tau_fem$tau ~ sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange))), col = "#20B2AA", lwd = 3, lty = 3)

#Add a legend
outer_legend("right",
             c("Gonad", "Liver", "Gill"),
             col = c("#EEB422", "#EE8262", "#20B2AA"),
             pch = 19,
             lwd = 3,
             bty = 'n',
             cex = 1.5,
             lty = 1:3,
             ncol = 1)


```

There appears to be a relationship between $\tau$ and female bias for the gonads and the liver, but potentially not for the gills. This may be due to a low number of female-biased genes. We can look further into this relationship with a Spearman's rank correlation test. This was done between $\tau$ and the $|log2FoldChange|$ for each organ separately.

```{r tau-v-bias-cor-fem, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
cor.test(gonad_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem, sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")
cor.test(liver_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem, sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")
cor.test(gill_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem, sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")

```

We can see a significant positive correlation in the gonads and liver, but no significant correlation in the gills.

## $\tau$ and logFC for all the signficantly expressed genes in each organ
Only looking at the logFC for the female-biased genes may be affecting the relationship that I am seeing between sex bias and $\tau$, especially in the organs where the samples size is very small if I am only including sex-biased genes (like the liver and gills). 

I used the same steps as above to see how the relationship changes when I add in ALL of the genes that are significantly expressed for each organ. In this datasets I have removed all rows where the adjusted p-value is NA (outliers and low-counts).

```{r tau-v-fem-bias-UB, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Female bias versus tissue specificity (tau) for all genes that are female biased in the gonads, liver, and gills."}

#Pull out both female-biased and unbiased 
liver_FB_UB <- liver_res[
  which((liver_res$log2FoldChange <= -2 & liver_res$padj <= 0.05) | 
         (liver_res$padj > 0.05)), ]

gonad_FB_UB <- gonad_res[
  which((gonad_res$log2FoldChange <= -2 & gonad_res$padj <= 0.05) | 
         (gonad_res$padj > 0.05)), ]

gill_FB_UB <- gill_res[
  which((gill_res$log2FoldChange <= -2 & gill_res$padj <= 0.05) | 
         (gill_res$padj > 0.05)), ]

#Merge the sex bias information with the tau values based on row names for each organ
liver_FB_UB_tau <- merge(as.data.frame(liver_FB_UB), as.data.frame(tau_fem), by = "row.names")
gonad_FB_UB_tau <- merge(as.data.frame(gonad_FB_UB), as.data.frame(tau_fem), by = "row.names")
gill_FB_UB_tau <- merge(as.data.frame(gill_FB_UB), as.data.frame(tau_fem), by = "row.names")

#Plot the relationship between FC (bias) and tau for each organ
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 8.1), xpd=FALSE)
plot(sqrt(abs(gonad_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange)),
     gonad_FB_UB_tau$tau,
     pch=19,
     col = "#EEB42275",
     xlab="Female bias (|log2 fold change|)",
     ylab=expression(tau_fem["TPM"]))
points(sqrt(abs(liver_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange)),
     liver_FB_UB_tau$tau,
     pch=19,
     col="#EE826275")
points(sqrt(abs(gill_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange)),
     gill_FB_UB_tau$tau,
     pch=19,
     col = "#20B2AA75")


#Add the best fit lines
abline(lm(gonad_FB_UB_tau$tau_fem ~ sqrt(abs(gonad_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange))), col="#EEB422", lwd = 3)
abline(lm(liver_FB_UB_tau$tau_fem ~ sqrt(abs(liver_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange))), col = "#EE8262", lwd = 3, lty = 2)
abline(lm(gill_FB_UB_tau$tau_fem ~ sqrt(abs(gill_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange))), col = "#20B2AA", lwd = 3, lty = 3)

#Add a legend
outer_legend("right",
             c("Gonad", "Liver", "Gill"),
             col = c("#EEB422", "#EE8262", "#20B2AA"),
             pch = 19,
             lwd = 3,
             bty = 'n',
             cex = 1.5,
             lty = 1:3,
             ncol = 1)


```

We can see wildly different patterns now: when we add in all of the points it seems that the best fit line for the gonads now points downward and the best fit line points upward. Let's see how the Spearman's rank correlation test have changed. This was done between $\tau$ and the $|log2FoldChange|$ for each organ separately.

```{r tau-v-FC-cor, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
cor.test(gonad_FB_UB_tau$tau_fem, abs(gonad_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange), method = "spearman")
cor.test(liver_FB_UB_tau$tau_fem, abs(liver_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange), method = "spearman")
cor.test(gill_FB_UB_tau$tau_fem, abs(gill_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange), method = "spearman")

```

## Categories of sex bias vs $\tau$

To further investigate the relationship between $\tau$ and sex biased and possibly get a cleaner idea of what may be going on I categorised the sex biased genes based on a series of logFC thresholds. After that I can plot $\tau$ against the bias level.

### Within the sex-biased genes

```{r bias-bin-cats-fem, echo=FALSE}
#Create a long format dataset that has the tissue information, logFC, tau, and geneID 
logFC_long_fem <- data.frame(
  tissue=c(rep("Gill", nrow(gill_bias_tau_fem)),
           rep("Gonad", nrow(gonad_bias_tau_fem)),
           rep("Liver", nrow(liver_bias_tau_fem))),
  logFC=c(gill_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange,
          gonad_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange,
          liver_bias_tau_fem$log2FoldChange),
  geneID=c(gill_bias_tau_fem$Row.names,
           gonad_bias_tau_fem$Row.names,
           liver_bias_tau_fem$Row.names),
  tau=c(gill_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem,
        gonad_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem,
        liver_bias_tau_fem$tau_fem)
  )

#Add a column to denote female-biased or male biased
logFC_long_fem$bias <- ifelse(logFC_long_fem$logFC < 0, paste0("FB"), paste0("MB"))

#Categorize the degree of sex bias in each row
#Make a vector that contains all of the groupings
biased_bins <- c("low", "med", "high", "extreme", "sex-specific")

#Create a new column in the dataset and use ifelse statements to set the category limits
#abs(logFC) was used to account for the fem-biased genes possessing negative values
logFC_long_fem$bias_cat <- ifelse(abs(logFC_long_fem$logFC) >= 2 & abs(logFC_long_fem$logFC) < 3, biased_bins[1],
                                   ifelse(abs(logFC_long_fem$logFC) >= 3 & abs(logFC_long_fem$logFC) < 5, biased_bins[2],
                                          ifelse(abs(logFC_long_fem$logFC) >= 5 & abs(logFC_long_fem$logFC) < 10,
                                                 biased_bins[3], 
                                                 biased_bins[4])
                                          )
                                   )

#Making sure the ordering stays correct
logFC_long_fem$bias_cat <- factor(logFC_long_fem$bias_cat,
    levels = biased_bins, ordered = TRUE)

#write.csv(logFC_long, "data/logFC_long_taubiasFB.csv", row.names = FALSE)

```

```{r tau-v-biascat-plot-fem, echo=FALSE, fig.width=15, fig.height=8, fig.cap="Tissue specificity (tau) across the different bias levels. Colour denotes female-biased versus male biased and jitters were added to show all of the raw tau values."}

plotdat +

### Across all significantly expressed genes
I want to see how $\tau$ in unbiased genes compares to these categories as well. To do that I recreated the long-style dataset to include all of the sig. expressed genes rather than just the sex-biased genes.

```{r bias-bin-cats-FBUB, echo=FALSE}
#Create a long format dataset that has the tissue information, logFC, tau, and geneID 
logFC_long_FBUB <- data.frame(

           rep("Gonad", nrow(gonad_FB_UB_tau)),

         ),
  logFC=c(gill_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange,
          gonad_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange,
          liver_FB_UB_tau$log2FoldChange
          ),
  geneID=c(gill_FB_UB_tau$Row.names,
           gonad_FB_UB_tau$Row.names,
           liver_FB_UB_tau$Row.names
           ),

        gonad_FB_UB_tau$tau,
        liver_FB_UB_tau$tau
        ),
  padj=c(gill_FB_UB_tau$padj,
         gonad_FB_UB_tau$padj,
         liver_FB_UB_tau$padj)
  
)

#Add a column to denote female-biased or male biased
logFC_long_FBUB$bias <- ifelse(logFC_long_FBUB$logFC <= -2 & 
                                logFC_long_FBUB$padj <= 0.05,
                              paste0("FB"),
                              ifelse(logFC_long_FBUB$logFC >= 2 &
                                       logFC_long_FBUB$padj <= 0.05,
                                     paste0("MB"),
                                     paste0("UB")
                                     )
                              )
  
#Categorize the degree of sex bias in each row
#Make a vector that contains all of the groupings

#abs(logFC) was used to account for the fem-biased genes possessing negative values
logFC_long_FBUB$bias_cat <- ifelse(logFC_long_FBUB$bias == "UB", 
                              biased_bins[1],
                              ifelse(abs(logFC_long_FBUB$logFC) >= 2 &

                                            biased_bins[3],
                                            ifelse(abs(logFC_long_FBUB$logFC) >= 5 &

                                                   biased_bins[4],
                                                   biased_bins[5])
                                            )
                                     )
                              )
  

#Making sure the ordering stays correct

    levels = biased_bins, ordered = TRUE)

logFC_long_FBUB$tissue <- factor(logFC_long_FBUB$tissue, levels = c("Gonad", "Liver", "Gill"), ordered = TRUE)

plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[1]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[2]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[3]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[4]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[5]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[6]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[7]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[8]), intgroup="organ")
plotCounts(dds_SN, gene= names(bot_tau_mal[9]), intgroup="organ")

```

We can see that for the male genes that have high tau values the plots of the normalised counts are more consistently showing higher expression in just that tissue compared to when we included both male and female genes, but there are still a few plots that show high expression in more than one tissue. The plots of the median and lower tau values no clear patterns are showing up in the plots of the counts. This is what we want to see, increasing confidence that the the calculations of tau are accurate.

# Sex Bias and Tissue Specificity
Now that I have calculated male $\tau$ I want to relate it back to information about sex bias to see what, if any, relationship exists. I am going to do this separately for the different organs to see if the relationship changes based on organ type. Now, I'll only be looking at male-biased genes.

## $\tau$ and logFC in male-biased genes for each organ
A gene was determined to be sex-biased if it had a log-fold change $\ge 2$ AND an adjusted p-value of $< 0.05$. Earlier I read in four datasets that contain information for all of the significantly expressed genes in each organ (i.e., the genes that were not given a p-value of NA from DESeq). 

From these datasets I can pull out the female-biased genes to plot logFC against $\tau$ within the genes that are sex-biased.

```{r tau-v-bias-mal, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Sex bias (in terms of the square root of the absolute value of the log2FoldChange) versus tissue specificity (tau) for all genes that are sex biased in the gonads, liver, and skin."}

#Pull out the male-biased genes (based on FC of >= 2 and padj of < 0.05) for each organ
liver_biased_mal <- liver_res[which(liver_res$log2FoldChange >= 2 & liver_res$padj <= 0.05),]
gonad_biased_mal <- gonad_res[which(gonad_res$log2FoldChange >= 2 & gonad_res$padj <= 0.05),]
gill_biased_mal <- gill_res[which(gill_res$log2FoldChange >= 2 & gill_res$padj <= 0.05),]


#Merge the sex bias information with the tau values based on row names for each organ
liver_bias_tau_mal <- merge(as.data.frame(liver_biased_mal), as.data.frame(tau_mal), by = "row.names")
gonad_bias_tau_mal <- merge(as.data.frame(gonad_biased_mal), as.data.frame(tau_mal), by = "row.names")
gill_bias_tau_mal <- merge(as.data.frame(gill_biased_mal), as.data.frame(tau_mal), by = "row.names")

#Plot the relationship between FC (bias) and tau for each organ
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 8.1), xpd=FALSE)
plot(sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange)),
     gonad_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal,
     pch=19,
     col = "#EEB42275",
     xlab="Male bias (|log2 fold change|)",
     ylab=expression(tau["TPM"]))
points(sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange)),
     liver_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal,
     pch=19,
     col="#EE826275")
points(sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange)),
     gill_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal,
     pch=19,
     col = "#20B2AA75")


#Add the best fit lines
abline(lm(gonad_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal ~ sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange))), col="#EEB422", lwd = 3)
abline(lm(liver_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal ~ sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange))), col = "#EE8262", lwd = 3, lty = 2)
abline(lm(gill_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal ~ sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange))), col = "#20B2AA", lwd = 3, lty = 3)

#Add a legend
outer_legend("right",
             c("Gonad", "Liver", "Gill"),
             col = c("#EEB422", "#EE8262", "#20B2AA"),
             pch = 19,
             lwd = 3,
             bty = 'n',
             cex = 1.5,
             lty = 1:3,
             ncol = 1)


```

There appears to be a relationship between $\tau$ and male bias for the gonads, liver, and the gills. This may be due to a low number of male-biased genes. We can look further into this relationship with a Spearman's rank correlation test. This was done between $\tau$ and the $|log2FoldChange|$ for each organ separately.

```{r tau-v-bias-cor-mal, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
cor.test(gonad_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal, sqrt(abs(gonad_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")
cor.test(liver_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal, sqrt(abs(liver_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")
cor.test(gill_bias_tau_mal$tau_mal, sqrt(abs(gill_bias_tau_mal$log2FoldChange)), method = "spearman")

```

We can see a significant positive correlation in the gonads and liver, but no significant correlation in the gills.
